threads.com:
/vst/ is a place to discuss all types of strategy video games, including both turn-based and real-time strategy, turn-based and real-time tactics, single-player and multi-player (including MOBAs). All platforms are welcome.

Does this mean discussion of strategy games is banned on other video game boards? No! /vst/ is just a separate board specifically focused on strategy games where discussions about your favorite games can thrive.

Please familiarize yourself with the rules and remember to use the spoiler function where appropriate!

Please note that, like /v/, "Generals"—long-term, one-after-the-other, recurring threads about a specific game are not permitted on /vst/. Such threads belong on >>>/vg/

I'm a boomer that finally moved on from civ 3 to civ 4. Enjoying it immensely, actually pretty close to the same game.

Is my mistake being lazy and not specializing each city? Do i need to pump out workers earlier on than civ 3?
Actually my problem might be lack of understanding of how to use the new Civic systems. Any tips are greatly appreciated.

Meulan was a lordship between France and Normandy, it contained a major bridge between the two. And the lords of Meulan were direct vassals of the French King.
However, the Lord of Meulan was one of William's companions, and made the earl of Leicester after the conquest, which he held from the King of England.
Later, his son inherited both titles, and found himself in an awkward situation, when the king of France invaded through Meulan and he just let him because he was his vassal.
As the result, the Normans arrested him, and revoked all his land in England and Normandy, later he escaped French king allowed him to keep Meulan because it wasn't part of Normandy and he had stayed loyal to him.

So, a good thing lasted until the lieges went to war.

How would you handle seasonal campaigning? So far as I know few wargames have attempted it, and it's normally something like an increased rate of attrition in winter, or in the case of WW2 games stuff like attacking a bit earlier than the historical barbarossa. I'm interested to see if Fields of Glory kingdoms will attempt to handle it.

As a feature I think it would be good because it would appeal to my historical autism, increase my immersion, make armies feel less like 'units' and more like people, and require better strategic planning than typical grand slopegy fare of just marching across the border, carpet sieging the whole state and painting the map.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1261007
It didnt cease for all of winter, but it was mostly just small war--raids, dozens of men trying to take a watch tower, cavalry torching up supplies and scaring peasants. You aren't going to get a lot of guys eager to march around during the winter, its easier for them to stay in their siege camps and enjoy the harvest as their enemy starves out in their castles.
Of course, there were occasions for marching during the winter and fighting battles like the Teutons at the Battle on the Ice or the German anti-King being slaughtered in the frozen marshes of Frisia

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1260782
you'd need proper logistical mechanics (supply lines, storage and foraging), any attempt without such a system would be shitty and based on artificial modifiers that would do little justice to the concept

the reduced amount of supplies to forage would be compounded by the effects of winter (attrition, reduced army movement speed) to result in winter warfare being substantially slower and reliant on the supplies of nearby friendly settlements
one who ignores these facts and goes deep into enemy territory during winter would find his supply routes be compromised and foraging/pillaging having low food yield, forcing him to either retreat or have his army starve (resulting in massive attrition and potentially a mutiny)

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1260782
Assuming we are talking about agrarian, feudal societies it depends on the complexity of the society's political system and social hierarchy. Low level, decentralized societies (Iron age-early medieval, continues in some marginal places like Ireland) had militaries centred around the minority of warrior aristocrats and their retinues. They are small in number, mobile and can wage war without supply penalties because they loot, forage and command enough supplies to wage war over a long period of time. However they have little incentive to go to war for campaigns lasting more than a few months outside the spring and summer and automatically disband after their short term goal is achieved, because they have to tend to their own livestock and crops and peasants. If for some reason your armies continue to wage war at this stage into the winter you will not suffer resource debuffs (the peasants are still on the farm sewing and harvesting crops; it's only the aristocrats who fight) but you should suffer from some administrative debuff from having your realm's law and order away fighting wars, and the potential for rebellion/instability from the nobles themselves.

When warfare starts to grow more large scale like in high-late medieval periods, your armies are composed of a core of men at arms and a mass of peasant levies. These armies also require loot and foraging to keep themselves supplied but a consequence of taking your peasants away from sewing and harvesting seasons is that you will suffer from food shortages, peasant unrest and even famine. This leads to the logical conclusion of warfare in the late medieval ages, which is to rely on mercenary companies who also require loot and forage and are exorbitantly expensive to maintain, but you won't suffer from food shortages and poor harvests. Your population by this time will be much greater and you should have less incentive to rely on levies.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1261160
Warfare is largely based around long, protracted sieges of enemy settlements which are usually clustered together. Units generally have poor health and your "massive" (unit capped) attacking army will start haemorrhaging losses once you attack an enemy settlement en masse. You have to constantly pump reinforcements into the battle while the enemy does the same, and usually you end up capturing a settlement on the outskirts of their capital and repeat the process over and over. Makes for cool Stalingrad-esque urban combat in the industrial era but doesn't make too much sense in ancient or medieval times.

Because they have made AI insanely rational, so they are unwilling to take risks.
AI will only attack opponents that have significantly fewer troops than them, which is why you never see Byzantines and Abbasids going at it, as they have roughly the same number of troops.
If Alexander was a CK character, he wouldn't have ever invaded the Achaemenids because Achemenids outnumbered him heavily.

in the abstract, the issue is that blobs will just grow and annex weaker neighbors while ignoring other blobs that could challenge them.
AI factor in what it has to gain, only how easy something is, hence why Byzantines will conquer poorly defended and worthless Ruthenia rather than heavily defended bur rich Syria

>>1261162
Make sure you replenish your troops, which you can either do for free where they gain 10% of their CURRENT strength back a turn, or heal them inside a city which is able to produce that unit type. Specialisations are a very large part of warfare, and while it is expensive to kit out multiple cities, stables, shipyards and so on with the same specialisation, I highly recommend doing it anyway. As an example, your Peltast starts as a 3/3 attack/defence, after a stalemate battle it may go down to 1.7/2 attack/defence, in which case using the free recovery would make it 1.87/2.2 attack/defence, and take another several turns to heal properly. Much better to send it back and heal it. In my first multiplayer game, the person playing Athens didn't recover his troops to the extent even Hades' Warriors were killing his Hoplites.

>>1260248
>OP
I wanted to touch on this topic of spheric vs flat RTS.

I think a key element for spherical vs flat RTS is shared control-type pvp RTS matches. These usually have a higher unit cap, along with shared resource gathering/consumption. One aspect that I like spherical RTS over flat RTS, is that is gives the players an unintentional fog-of-war when viewing the battlefield from a casual strategic level (you can only see one half of a planet). It pushes for players on a team to focus on handling specific skirmishes at the low level occurring over the course of the big battle, since they have the most current situational awareness. It's a nice touch and I like the level of autonomy that happens during these shared control pvp matches.

I kinda wish there was a more popular RTS that had a shared-control and shared-resource army on bigger maps/solar system scale to incentivize players to split off into expeditionary branches of the main force for handling specific fronts.

Zero-K kind of has this system, where players tend to specialize in a certain type of army, but I hate how everyone in that game wants to forfeit after the slightest sign of not having overwhelming odds of winning. What's the point of having all these cool ass weapons if you don't get to wreck the enemy team with them. I like watching the absolute destruction of the enemy team, and I'm cool with trying to struggle to get back on top as the disadvantaged side. There's been plenty of matches in various RTS games where I thought we were losing, but after some extremely decisive blows to the enemy we ended up winning. Those are the best matches.

I hope this game has shared-control armies.

You'll do like 60 damage per shot (and more on a crit) and the necro will rarely target Canopus unless he's the only available target, so everyone else just plays defense until the necro is worn down by the pew pew. If you're doing well you can send one of the frontliners to beat on the necro to speed things up.

Or just backtrack, do some main story missions, and come back when you're level 7 or 8.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1246505
The biggest thing that you're probably not doing if the AI can beat you is magic. Magic is a huge deal in this game. You should be using all the gold that you don't need immediately for winning wars to get more mages – whichever ones give you the most research points per gold. Note that sacred mages have reduced upkeep compared to non-sacreds. You can see upkeep by clicking one of the stats on the unit thing – morale iirc, but I haven't played in a while so hat might have been one of the things they changed going to 5.

Anyway, you also need to evaluate spells. Look at what paths you have (elements) and see what's good. Spells are relatively easy to evaluate, since mostly you just need some badass effects and then counters for whatever your enemy is fielding – but most spells are situational and chances are AI won't field anything that means you need those spells. You can ask here or on /domg/ what your bread and butter spells for a given nation are likely to be.

Mind you, you also ought to be good at building a pretender but that's a lot more in-depth and you kind of have to know what the nation is like. You can ask for specifics about that too.

last_replies.com:
>Yes the Kane character is immortal. I intentionally spelled his name differently from "Cain" to add a little mystery.
The Brotherhood of Nod is a direct reference to the Land of Nod. Nod is where Cain went after he killed his brother Abel.
Kane can be maimed, injured, and even briefly "killed" but he is cursed by God and no matter how badly hurt, he will slowly but surely regenerate.
In my mind he spent long periods of history uninterested in human affairs, but occasionally he sees glimpses of a future in which he might escape his curse or settling for less, rule Humankind.
Kane was largely uninterested in human affairs most recently until the emergence of Tiberium. Before he even saw Tiberium himself or knew what it was, he started to have visions of the future again--strange and weird visions of a future Earth changed, a biosphere he couldn't recognize, and an outside agent from offworld. A future in which he was both freed from his curse and ruled Earth. And with that he steps forward and slowly emerges from the shadows with his new socio-political-religious movement and starts to influence things. He never sees future clearly and it's often very confusing and muddy visions that he catches. Kane completely believes he will be free from his curse and while he enjoys his power and ability to control the affairs of man, he really wants to die one day. He also believes he sees the only way for mankind to survive, as a species, into a very difficult future. He really believes his way is the only way forward. He's not your typical "bad guy"--but he is definitely pathological. He does everything that he does with righteous purpose and feels the ends justify the means. Keep in mind that while Kane has no empathy for others, he is fond of human race in general, and curious to see what becomes of it. He is especially intrigued by advanced sciences, medicine, electronics, and artificial intelligence.

Brett Sperry

>>1259005
>>1259009
https://eu3.paradoxwikis.com/Domestic_policy_sliders#Centralization_vs._Decentralization

Theres no benefit from not going as much centralized as your form of government allows, maybe even on step beyond that.
The only other related mechanic to keep track of is the overextension triggered modifier, which only ever matters if you have less than 50% (or something similar of your total provinces as core provinces. That means once you conquer enough land and hold it for 50 years, you wont have to bother with overextension any longer.

Additionally, once tech allows for it, you can spam cathedrals, giving you enormous free stability investment that like universities and manufacturies is added as bonus for each manual investment that you make, which gives you insane returns on your stability investments, even allowing for rapid government changes and truce breaking due to the ability to cheaply buy back you stability.

One slider that depends on circumstance is innovative vs narrowminded. If you're catholic, go narrowminded, as large catholic empires will have much greater chances to get new cardinals and take control of the holy see. For anyone else and catholics who stand as the only catholic nation left, lower tech cost afforded by innovative might be the better option.

There are non-exploitative ways to get rid of heat, but they are so incredibly inferior to steam turbine + aquatuner builds that nobody uses them, and the game is not "balanced" around them.
One way is to use an Anti Entropy Thermo-Nullifier, which you may or may not find on your asteroid. It is extremely weak in terms of cooling power and eats a good amount of hydrogen. Plus it can't cool all the way down to 0 K.
The other is to transfer the heat into a gas or liquid (ideally water) with an aquatuner and then dump the fluid into space. But not only do you pay insane amounts of energy for this, you also lose a substantial amount of mass, so it's only viable if you have a good number of water sources, which is completely up to chance.
You are basically expected to use exploits, it's asinine game design.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Why are hexfags so fucking retarded they cannot see the forest for the trees?

See picrel for why why the "diagonal movement problem" hexfags try to ascribe to squares doesn't actually exist - because you are moving in tiles, not actual distance! It doesn't matter that you have moved 1.41 feet diagonally, when you would have moved only 1 foot orthgonaly, becasue YOU ARE NOT MOVING IN REAL DISTANCE, YOU ARE MOVING IN TILES.
See picrel, it takes the exact same amount of tiles to move from one corner to the next diagonally, that it takes to move from one corner to the next orthogonally.
Yes the real distance is larger, but that does not matter, since the game is structured in tiles, not real distance!

Hexxfagging is unirinically Reddit-style thinking - believing you are some sort of expert and can overturn years of time-tested methods because you have learned some arbitrary fun fact (in this case that distance from one center of a square to the center of diagonal square is larger than the distance to the center of a orthogonal square).

TL;DR: 1 tile = 1 tile, always

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1228120
>>1231747
there's actually no fundamental difference in programming AI for hex vs square

your functions would just use a different algorithm, e.g. 'getAllInRange(type)' would just reference 'getHexList(radius)' instead of 'getSquareList(radius)

and the mathematics of hex vs square, hex is not a 'more restricted square board', it's a constraint of a cubic grid where x+y+z=0 - which means there's already algorithms written for it, you just apply the constraint

or even simpler, from the dev perspective you just find a hex grid library and everything is the same to you

notice how there's no games with a stackable multi-tiered hex grid (i.e. not like battle brothers), because at that point you have to have developers writing 4D algorithms

The intended idea is that you'd just stop to consider your actions and not do horrible things just because it's tree in a videogame you can max out. I never used the word medieval, but regardless it's silly to say that the setting for this fictional game is strictly analogous to a single time period like the fall of (West) Rome. The factions in the vanilla game themselves don't perfectly match up with that time period anyway. For example, the Battanians are clearly modeled after the Gauls, who had ceased to exist as an independent culture almost 5 centuries before the fall of West Rome. Vlandia, on the other hand, are a high-medieval inspired faction with crossbows and Norman-like aesthetics. TW took inspiration from various cultures stretching from antiquity to the early medieval for Bannerlord. I think the feudalesque recruitment of the De Re Military mod matches the setting of this game just fine.

>fell off hard by the medieval era... I guess I'm not aggressive enough with the cities.
Medieval era is when city population should start booming and where worked cottages start fully growing. Without seeing anything I will diagnose the fall off as not having enough workers, not enough cottage tiles grown,and low city population. If you have tech trading on I'll also add that you should prioritize key techs more and trade with AI for techs you don't really need, but you have to pay attention to the trade screen and not trade away your important techs for garbage. If almost everyone has mathematics and one AI offers you a 2 turn tech for math it still could be a good deal because the tech is low value at that point for example.
